bioghist.p: Founded in 1840 by seventeen prominent Philadelphians, and led by Eli Kirk Price, Woodlands Cemetery is the final resting place for numerous local and national figures. The aim of the founding members was to create a peaceful sanctuary by "removing the dead from the midst of the dense population of our cities, and placing them in operation with beautiful works of nature; thus making them the means of preserving open spaces and some of the finest park scenery near our town which otherwise would be prostrated in the progress of building improvements." Some of the notables buried here include Thomas Eakins, Sydney George Fisher, Rembrandt Peale, Eli Kirk Price and Eli Kirk Price II.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the records of the Woodlands Cemetery Company. Records include: annual reports to Corporators, 1844-1851; ledgers, 1889-1934; daybooks, 1889-1932; cashbooks, 1889-1935; Superintendent's weekly reports, 1886-1931; letterpress books, 1891-1933, minute books; receipt books; receipts and lists of manager's expenses; burial reports; and correspondence. Additionally there is correspondence relating to the demolition of the 19th century entrance and construction of a new entrance according to designs of Paul Cret, 1936-1937. The collection also includes materials related to the estates of Eli K. Price, John Sargeant Price, and Elizabeth Price Martin. These materials consist of wills, correspondence regarding property appraisals, lease and purchase agreements, and proposed building plans.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
